I've been happily using JUnit for years (v3.8.1), and I currently find
myse=
lf in a situation that requires me to get additional info into the
JUnit HT=
ML report; the default HTML report is no longer sufficient for
our uses.  S=
ome issues I have include:

1. We have many test cases and test suites, and=
 it is common to
duplicate a method name in more than one test case.  e.g.
=
testAccessProperties() may appear many times, so if one of them fails,
its =
not readily obvious WHICH one failed.  I usually have included the
name of =
the test case in the test method's name, but other developers
here aren't w=
illing to do that.  e.g.
"testOurTestCase_accessProperties".  Test case inf=
o should appear in
the results too so that we don't have to creatively name=
 the methods.

2. I'm producing one giant HTML report from the running of s=
everal
test suites.  Each test suite is usually named AllTests.  The
result=
ing HTML shows a list of test cases all named AllTests, which
isn't all tha=
t helpful.

3. It is normal for us to run the same test suite more than onc=
e, but
with different data each time.  For example, our product has a commo=
n
interface to access more than one type of server, so the same set of
test=
s are invoked against more than one server (and this is controlled
by provi=
ding a .properties file to the tests containing different info
about that s=
erver).  The default behavior of the JUnit ant task
created a file TEST-com=
.blah.AllTests.xml file which kept getting
overwritten with each subsequent=
 run of the tests against another
server; I solved this with the "outfile" =
attribute so that each XML
file has a slightly different name, so I can at =
least preserve the
data.  But, the one giant HTML report isn't able to show=
 how one test
run is any different from another since it just lists
"com.bl=
ah.AllTests" several times.  I need a way to annotate in the
test results w=
hat each test run was for, even just a simple text
string would help.

I re=
alize some of these problems could be solved just by creating
several diffe=
rent HTML reports, each in its own directory appropriate
named, and a highe=
r-level HTML file with text descriptions and links
to each HTML report.  Al=
though, we'd kind of like one big report.

Has anyone else worked out issue=
s like these?  I have done a small
amount of extending JUnit (custom format=
ters, custom runners), so I'm
not afraid of proceeding down that path.  Any=
one have tips on what has
worked out well for them?

Thanks!
